stem: A 34-year-old client with a T4 spinal cord injury (SCI) suddenly reports a 'splitting headache' and becomes flushed above the chest. Based on the documentation in the Critical Neuro Monitoring & Trigger Assessment tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute hypertensive emergency in a chronic SCI patient.
Background: T4 level injury (5 years ago). Indwelling Foley catheter present.
Assessment: BP has spiked to 198/112. Client is sweating profusely and has 'goosebumps' on his legs.
Recommendation: Immediate trigger identification and HOB elevation.

tabs.title: Trigger Assessment Log
tabs.content:
SourceAssessmentResult
BladderFoley Catheter tubingKinked under the client's thigh
BowelPalpation of lower quadrantDistended (Last BM 3 days ago)
SkinToes / SheetsToenail is ingrown and red

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 198/112, HR 48 (Bradycardia), RR 22, T 98.4Â°F. Flushed above T4; Pale below T4.

actionOptions.text: Immediately elevate the head of the bed to 90 degrees (High-Fowler's)
Check for and remove the stimulus (Unkink the foley/Catheterize)
Administer IV Propranolol to increase the heart rate
Place the client in a Trendelenburg position to support perfusion

parameterOptions.text: Continuous blood pressure and heart rate monitoring
Patency of the urinary drainage system and bowel status
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Autonomic Dysreflexia (AD) (c1), a life-threatening complication of SCI at T6 or above. The kinked Foley (Trigger) causes a massive sympathetic surge below the injury level, leading to vasoconstriction and severe HTN. The body attempts to compensate with bradycardia (HR 48). Priority action #1 is elevating the HOB (a1) to use gravity to drop the BP. Priority action #2 is finding and removing the trigger (a2) (unkinking the tube). Monitoring focuses on the BP (p1) and trigger status (p2).
clinicalPearls: Any noxious stimulus below the level of injury (full bladder, full bowel, tight shoe, ingrown nail) can trigger AD.
Flushed Above / Pale Below: This is because the brain can only vasodilate above the injury level to try and drop the pressure.
If the BP remains high after the trigger is removed, hydralazine or nitrates may be used.

questionTrap.trap: Calling a Rapid Response before elevating the HOB.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Elevation is the FIRST and MOST EFFECTIVE way to drop the BP immediately while waiting for help. Do it first!

mnemonic.title: B-B-B-B (AD Triggers)
mnemonic.expansion: B-Bladder (Full/Kinked). B-Bowel (Impacted). B-Back (Pressure sores). B-Binding (Tight clothes).
